Award.AwardTitle: Novel graphene-based electronic devices integratible with silicon: synergistic research across materials, concepts, and implementation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to demonstrate novel silicon-integratible graphene-based
devices, including the metal-oxide-graphene-silicon field-effect transistor to achieve drain
current saturation with a zero bandgap, and the graphene-insulator-graphene junction to achieve
resonance tunneling. These devices are expected to harness the enormous momentum behind
silicon manufacturing, exploit the unique advantages graphene while circumventing serious
challenges, thus find niche applications for technology entry, and eventually enter the
mainstream digital arena with full potential enabled by future progress.
Intellectual merit: This project represents coherent research efforts spanning materials, concepts,
and implementation. The materials growth research will seek answers to fundamental questions
about heteroepitaxy of two-dimensional layers. Novel device concepts, with deep roots in
proven ideas (modulation doping and resonant tunneling), uniquely take advantage of the
material properties. Implementation of the concepts incorporates realistic engineering
considerations from materials and processing to structures and modeling, and represents sound
engineering practice.
Broader impact: New discoveries will be introduced to undergraduate and graduate students, not
only to convey knowledge, but also to stimulate curiosity and enthusiasm. Outreach activities
such as the PI's partnership with a local high school will impact K-12 science and math
education. The nature of the proposed research provides an excellent multidisciplinary research
platform for graduate students. This project will enhance diversity by involving and training
female graduate students and by recruiting young minds from underrepresented groups. The
success of this research will potentially create US jobs by complementing the dominant, largely
overseas silicon-based fabrication with graphene-based niche technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program aimed at schemes of graphene-based, silicon-integratible electronic devices for practical applications.  Due to the lack of a band gap, two-dimensional (2D), unmodified graphene does not provide a switching solution for conventional digital logic. Unlike schemes involving band gap creation, we addressed concepts taking advantage of certain aspects of the physical properties of graphene without creating a band gap for specialized applications.  Therefore, the long-term goal of the research was not to replace silicon, but is heterogeneous integration. 

In the early stages of the program, the focus was on the growth of graphene and its insulator companion -- hexagonal boron nitride, a 2D material isostructural to graphene needed in graphene-based devices.  The materials growth work resulted in the demonstration of the new concept of "heteroepitaxy in two dimensions" through the synthesis and characterization of graphene/h-BN in-plane heterostructures (see accompanying image).  This work significantly impacted the field of 2D materials by inspiring a large number of works on in-plane heterostructures of 2D materials. Among the several significant publications resulted from this work, our earliest report [Liu et al, Science 343, 163 (2014)] had received 259 citations by September 2018.  

Later stages of the program gradually shifted towards the fabrication and characterization as well as theoretical analysis of graphene-based devices. The focus was on the modulation of graphene conductivity, which we considered to be the most critical prerequisite for graphene-based field-effect transistors to ever become practical for any applications. Our theoretical analysis identified the fundamental limits to the modulation of graphene conductivity at ambient conditions. We also defined figures of merits and outlined paths for optimization. Our experimental work investigated methods for minimizing the minimum carrier concentration, the most critical limit to the conductivity modulation of graphene. 

This program supported a female PhD student throughout the entire performance period resulting in her graduation and degree, and also supported 3 MS students from under-represented communities in an HBCU, contributing to the diversity of STEM fields. Overall, a total of 9 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral researchers had received training to various extents in this program.
